mechanismDescription: Nepal's 2024 transitional justice law aims to address human rights violations from the 1996-2006 civil conflict between government forces and Maoist insurgents. The amnesty provisions allow individuals involved in "violations of human rights," such as lesser offenses, to avoid prosecution if they disclose the truth, apologize, or compensate victims. Actors eligible for amnesty include members of both state security forces and Maoist combatants, excluding those responsible for "serious violations of human rights," such as war crimes, genocide, or extreme forms of torture and sexual violence. The Bill comes after agreement between the Nepali Congress, Communist Party of Nepal-Unified Marxist Leninist (CPN-UML), and Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Center).
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi népalaise de 2024 sur la justice transitionnelle vise à remédier aux violations des droits de la personne commises lors du conflit civil de 1996-2006 entre les forces gouvernementales et les insurgés maoïstes. Les dispositions relatives à l'amnistie permettent aux personnes impliquées dans des « violations des droits de la personne », telles que des infractions mineures, d'éviter les poursuites si elles révèlent la vérité, présentent des excuses ou dédommagent les victimes. Les acteurs pouvant bénéficier de l'amnistie sont les membres des forces de sécurité de l'État et les combattants maoïstes, à l'exclusion des personnes responsables de « violations graves des droits de la personne », telles que les crimes de guerre, les génocides ou les formes extrêmes de torture et de violence sexuelle. Le projet de loi est le fruit d'un accord entre le Congrès népalais, le Parti communiste du Népal - marxiste léniniste unifié (CPN-UML) et le Parti communiste du Népal (centre maoïste).
amnestyName: Bill to Amend the Enforced Disappearances Enquiry, Truth and Reconciliation Commission Act, 2071
narrative: Nepal's 2024 transitional justice amendment, part of the "Bill to Amend the Enforced Disappearances Enquiry, Truth and Reconciliation Commission Act, 2071," seeks to address human rights violations from the 1996-2006 conflict. The law categorizes offenses as either "violations of human rights" or "serious violations of human rights." Offenses deemed as human rights violations may be eligible for amnesty, whereas serious violations could lead to prosecution in a special court. Critics argue that this classification might enable perpetrators of grave offenses to evade justice. The legislation allows for a 75% reduction in sentences for those convicted of serious human rights violations, provided they meet certain conditions, such as disclosing the truth, apologizing to victims, or offering compensation. This provision has been criticized for potentially serving as a disguised form of amnesty.
qualifyingProcess: "Application Submission: Individuals seeking amnesty must submit an application to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) or the Commission of Investigation on Enforced Disappeared Persons (CIEDP). The application must include details of the individual's involvement in the conflict and the specific actions for which they are seeking amnesty. Review of Application: The TRC or CIEDP will review the application to determine eligibility. This includes verifying the individual's involvement in the conflict and ensuring that the actions for which amnesty is sought fall within the scope of the law1. Public Hearings: In some cases, public hearings may be conducted to gather additional information and allow victims and witnesses to provide testimony. This helps ensure transparency and accountability in the amnesty process1. Decision: Based on the review and any public hearings, the commission will make a decision on whether to grant amnesty. The decision will take into account the nature of the crimes committed, the individual's role in the conflict, and the potential impact on victims and their families1. Reparations and Support: If amnesty is granted, the commission may recommend reparations and support for victims and their families"
whatCrimes: human rights violations; dissent / political crimes; armed opposition
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty

mechanismDescription: Decree No. 743 provided amnesty to civilians and military personnel, including members of the Sandinista Liberation Front, for political and associated common crimes
mechanismDescription_fr: Le décret n° 743 amnistie les civils et les militaires, y compris les membres du Front sandiniste de libération, pour les délits politiques et les délits de droit commun qui y sont associés.
narrative: On December 3, 1978, Nicaragua’s National Congress passed Decreto No. 743 Concédase Amplia e Incondicional Amnistía a Civiles y Militares, or Law No. 743, which was a full and unconditional amnesty law. This amnesty law covered civilians and military people convicted or charged of political or related common crimes. The also amnesty covered: fighting an insurgency (for military), those inducted since the previous amnesty law that pardon political crimes from March3, 1976 to December 11, 1978. The legislation was introduced because of demands from opposition political parties. It went into effect on December 13, 1978. The amnesty covered 4,000 people, including political prisoners and exiles, and members of the Sandinista Liberation Front. In pardoning exiles, the Consuls of Nicaragua abroad were to immediately give passports to those who wished to return back. In order to receive amnesty, members of the Sandinista Liberation Front must surrender their weapons. The amnesty also applies to common and civil liability crimes.
whoWasAmnestied: state agents; armed opposition; refugees / exiles
qualifyingProcess: - Members of the Sandinista Liberation Front must lay down their weapons.

mechanismDescription: The military junta decreed an amnesty for all Miskito Indians and Nicaraguan citizens for crimes committed against state security, except for guerrillas responsible for terrorist attacks
mechanismDescription_fr: La junte militaire a décrété une amnistie pour tous les Indiens Miskito et les citoyens nicaraguayens pour les crimes commis contre la sécurité de l'État, à l'exception des guérilleros responsables d'attaques terroristes.
narrative: Ley No. 1352, Amnistía a Miskitos, Gaceta Nº 275, Decreto Nº 1352 de 1 de diciembre de 1983 was an amnesty law created in Nicaragua in 1983. The legislation went into effect on December 4, 1983. Daniel Ortega—the junta coordinator, read the decree at the closing of the National Congress’ session. The amnesty covered those who have been convicted or were involved in illegal acts against the public order and state from December 1, 1981. This covered not only Nicaraguans, but also Miskito Indians. In reality, the amnesty covered 10,000 insurgent fighters and thousands of exiles, who committed crimes against public security or related crimes against the state. Those who committed such crimes and fled the country are allowed to receive pardon and return back. The amnesty is offered until February 21, 1984, but it was extended until November 4, 1984. The amnesty excluded guerillas, who planned terrorist attacks.
qualifyingProcess: - The decree offered pardons until 21 Feb 1984. The amnesty was extended for successive periods up to 4 Nov 1984.

mechanismDescription: The Amnesty Law No. 1 provided amnesty to all counter-revolutionaries for participating in armed opposition
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi d'amnistie n° 1 prévoit l'amnistie de tous les contre-révolutionnaires ayant participé à l'opposition armée.
narrative: The National Assembly in Nicaragua passed Ley de Amnistía, Nº 1 and the amnesty law went into effect on January 29, 1985. The President in his inaugural speech introduced the amnesty. The legislation covers members of opposition group, who had taken arms against the state in an anti-government movement. Specifically, Article 1 states “All Nicaraguans who are actually involved in counter-revolutionary activities, including those of an armed nature.” This amnesty can be applied to leaders of these groups, who were previously excluded in past amnesties. Exiles in Honduras or Costa Rica were to give up arms to the governmental authorities in those countries, the International Red Cross, or Nicaraguan consulates. Members of these groups had to surrender their weapons to the Nicaraguan authority. The Nicaraguan Episcopal Conference deems this inclusion as a positive achievement. The amnesty was applicable until July 19, 1985, but it was extended until September 3, 1985, again until August 20, 1986, and lastly once again until July 27, 1987.
qualifyingProcess: - Valid until 19 Jul 1985. It was extended on 3 Sep 1985 and again on 20 Aug 1986 and on 27 Jul 1987. - Must surrender and hand over their weapons to the competent authorities (arts 1-2). Nicaraguans in Honduras or Costa Rica can take their weapons to the authorities of the governments in those countries, the international Red Cross, or Nicaraguan consulates (art 3).

mechanismDescription: The government extended a 1985 amnesty law for Contra rebels by one year
mechanismDescription_fr: Le gouvernement a prolongé d'un an la loi d'amnistie de 1985 pour les rebelles de la Contra.
narrative: Ley de Amnistía General, Nº 36 repealed the 1987 amnesty law and was approved by the National Assembly on April 24, 1988 after the Constitutional Government of Nicaragua and the Nicaraguan Resistance agreed to the Sapoá Accords on March 23, 1988. This amnesty law pardons army personnel for crimes committed before July 19, 1979. Article 3 guaranteed that the Sandinista government would grant amnesty to the former regime’s army members, who were charged for rebellious crimes and to those who were charged with violating the law on order and security. The amnesty also applies to all Contra leaders and members, even those outside the country. The amnesty went through three phases of releasing political prisoners instead of releasing everyone immediately. First, 100 prisoners were released on Palm Sunday (March 27, 1988), then half of the remaining Contra prisoners were released on April 15 when the Contras moved to designated ceasefire zones, and then once the ceasefire agreement was finalized, the remaining prisoners were released. The amnesty law was extended until December 23, 1988 and again on September 3, 1989.

mechanismDescription: The "Esuipulas II Agreement" provided amnesty to Nicaraguan nationals for offences related to violating laws concerning the maintenance of order and security
mechanismDescription_fr: L'"accord d'Esuipulas II" prévoit l'amnistie des ressortissants nicaraguayens pour les délits liés à la violation des lois relatives au maintien de l'ordre et de la sécurité.
narrative: Esuipulas II Agreement (Arias Plan) of August 7, 1987 was implemented through the November 19, 1987 Ley de Amnistía para Detenidos por Violación de la Ley de Mantenimiento del Orden y Seguridad Pública, No 33. The Sandinista government did not want to support the amnesty provisions as detailed in the Arias Peace Plan. There was a strong push from the human rights sector and inter-governmental organizations to get the amnesty through. The National Assembly passed the amnesty law on November 19, 1987. The amnesty law pardons Nicaraguans, who had been convicted and sentenced for violating laws regarding public order and security from July 20, 1979. The amnesty does not cover former members of the National Guard under the Somoza regime, who committed crimes against Nicaraguans because they were not sentenced under the Law on the maintenance of public order and security. Instead, they were trialed for violating a penal code that is not covered by the amnesty. Eventually, the amnesty was given to about 1,600 prisoners accused of Contra activity. The Sandinista government timed the releasing of these prisoners with funding decisions that US Congress made. On November 29, 1987, the Nicaraguan government gave amnesties to 985 prisoners. 779 of the prisoners were arrested and sentenced for violating the law on public order and security while the Special Courts convicted 206 of these prisoners.

mechanismDescription: Amnesty Law No. 100 decreed a general amnesty to all Nicaraguans, for political and related offences committed between 1979 and 1990, including human rights violations and repression
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi d'amnistie n° 100 a décrété une amnistie générale pour tous les Nicaraguayens, pour les délits politiques et connexes commis entre 1979 et 1990, y compris les violations des droits de la personne et la répression.
narrative: Not to be confused with Nicaragua 1990’s Law No. 81, this other 1990s amnesty is Law No. 100, which was a Presidential Decree approved by the National Assembly. It is also known as La Gaceta, N º 100, 23 May 1990, No. 98, p. 1064, which replaced Law No. 81 It was created on May 9, 1990. The legislation applies to “all those detained, prosecuted, sentenced, pending trial, still at large, and prisoners that have served out their sentence, as well as those who have been granted a simple pardon…” (Article 1). It also permits former Somoza guards and others to return back to their country. The amnesty also concerns those who were involved in political and related acts from before 1979 (the year of the dictator Somoza's downfall) to the present day.
whoWasAmnestied: state agents; protesters / political prisoners; armed opposition

mechanismDescription: Amnesty Law No. 81 provided a general amnesty to all Nicaraguans for crimes against order and state security, including human rights violations and repression, that occurred between July 19, 1979, and March 13, 1990
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi d'amnistie n° 81 prévoit une amnistie générale pour tous les Nicaraguayens ayant commis des crimes contre l'ordre et la sécurité de l'État, y compris des violations des droits de la personne et des actes de répression, entre le 19 juillet 1979 et le 13 mars 1990.
amnestyName: Ley de Amnistia General y Reconciliacion Nacional (Ley No.81)
narrative: Law No. 81, or 1990 Law on General Amnesty and National Reconciliation (Ley de amnistía general y reconciliación nacional, Nº 81) was repealed by Ley de amnistía of May 9, 1990. Amnesty Law No. 81 was passed on March 23, 1990 as a Presidential Decree. Nicaragua’s government passed this amnesty legislation in order to comply with the Arias Peace Plan of August 7, 1987. This amnesty is broad and unconditional for all Nicaraguans, meaning that it is not designated for the upper political class, but for any class of people. Article 1 grants amnesty to “all civilian and military Nicaraguans who may have committed infractions in the course of carrying out or investigating the criminal acts described in the preceding paragraph.” In other words, this amnesty excuses all governmental officials and army members, who may have broken the law or committed abuses in the past. This also covers economic crimes committed by government officials because of an occupational obligation. This amnesty applies to those who have been detained, awaiting trial, prosecuted, and in jail. The Sandinista government was hesitant to pardon those convicted and sentenced for human rights abuses and violations of humanitarian law. An agreement was reached in which the Commission would review “prisoners’ cases and distinguish between those in which notwithstanding the irregularities inherent in the Special Tribunals, there was overwhelming evidence of serious human rights violations, and those in which the evidence was insufficient to justify conviction. The Commission efficiently completed this review and recommended amnesty for the latter, and judicial review by Nicaragua’s regular courts for the former. The government, some months after receipt of the Commission’s report, freed most of the prisoners whose release the Commission recommended. Then, before leaving office, the Sandinistas freed all remaining political prisoners and made the amnesty complete by granting amnesty to all officials for the same crimes committed in public office.” (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database).
whoWasAmnestied: state agents; protesters / political prisoners; armed opposition
qualifyingProcess: The 1991 law extended the amnesty period provided for in the May 1990 law until 22 Dec 1991.
whatCrimes: corruption or other economic crimes; human rights violations; armed opposition

mechanismDescription: President Violeta Chamorro decreed an amnesty for detainees, accused, wanted, and convicted Nicaraguans for political offences, politically motivated crimes, and human rights violations
mechanismDescription_fr: La présidente Violeta Chamorro a décrété une amnistie pour les détenus, les accusés, les personnes recherchées et les Nicaraguayens condamnés pour des délits politiques, des crimes à motivation politique et des violations des droits de la personne.
narrative: The Nicaraguan Congress approved Ley de Amnistía, Discréto No. 47-91 on December 28, 1991. The amnesty covers anyone detained, on trial, sentenced, awaiting trial, or not captured but wanted, and those serving their sentence for political or related crimes, or common crimes that were politically motivated. Those who have served their sentence will be pardoned. It covers the time period from May 10, 1990 to the implementation of this amnesty legislation. The amnesty is broad and unconditional, requiring the immediate release of those imprisoned or held. The amnesty law excuses serious human rights violations. Since Nicaragua adopted the Convention on the Imprescriptibility of War Crimes and Crimes against Humanity, the amnesty does not cover war crimes.
whoWasAmnestied: protesters / political prisoners; regular convicts; armed opposition
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were included in amnesty

mechanismDescription: Amnesty Law No. 163 provided a general amnesty to Nicaraguan insurgents for political and associated common crimes, such as armed rebellion against the government, prior to August 28, 1993
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi d'amnistie n° 163 prévoit une amnistie générale pour les insurgés nicaraguayens ayant commis des délits politiques et des délits de droit commun connexes, tels que la rébellion armée contre le gouvernement, avant le 28 août 1993.
narrative: Ley de Amnistía, Ley Nº 163, or Amnesty Law No. 163 went into effect on September 23, 1993. The National Assembly approved the legislation on August 17, 1993 with support from 45/92 Sandinista deputies. Before voting, the UNO withdrew their support from the process because of their discontent with the amnesty and Junta Directiva. Article 1 of the amnesty legislation states that the law covers anyone who took up arms because of political objectives or for socio-economic reasons until August 28, 1993. This date was extended to cover the rearmed groups that tookover the city of Estelí and other groups, who took hostages in the Quilalí municipal and in the UNO headquarters in Managua. It also covers “Nicaraguan members of irregular groups belonging to the self-styled ‘Frente Norte 3-80’ and ‘Commando Dignity and Sovereignty’ for the political and related common crimes committed with the reason of kidnapping, which occurred in Aug 1993 in the town of Zúngano, Municipality of Quilalí, and at the headquarters of the Union Nacional Opositora (UNO) in Managua” (Mallinder Amnesty Law Database). Those who want amnesty must voluntarily give up their weapons and military equipment no later than September 15, 1993 to security zones established by the government.
qualifyingProcess: - time limit by 28 Aug 1993. - Must demobilise voluntarily surrender their weapons and military equipment not later than 15 Sep 1993 by joining the security zones previously established by the ministry of governance by 28 Aug 1993 (art 3) Covers those who already demobilised between 18 May 1993 and the entry into force of the law (art 3). Covering Nicaraguan members of irregular groups belonging to the self- styled ?Frente Norte 3-80? and ?Commando Dignity and Sovereignty? for the political and related common crimes committed with the reason of kidnapping, which occurred in Aug 1993 in the town of Zúngano, Municipality of Quilalí, and at the headquarters of the Union Nacional Opositora (UNO) in Managua, without having to comply with requirements that to qualify for amnesty must voluntarily appear before the Representative of the Ministry of the Interior established for such purposes, and then get the Charter Demobilization referred to in the preceding article of this Act.(art 5)

narrative: This amnesty law was approved by the Legislative Assembly and ratified by President Eric Arturo Devalle. It went to effect on July 14, 1987. There are speculations that the amnesty was proposed on behalf of General Antonio Noreiga. This legislation grants amnesty to political prisoners, who were arrested in a violent anti-government protest weeks prior to the introduction of the bill, or since June 8, 1987. This includes about 700 Panamanians, who committed criminal acts and 90 people who were allegedly involved in political crimes. Amongst those granted amnesty is Colonel Roberto Diaz Herrara, a retired former Chief of Staff of the Panamanian Defense Forces. Exiled leaders of the anti-government movement were also granted immunity, including Aurelio Antonio Barria—Chairman of the Chamber of Commerce. However, political prisoners, who committed crimes against state institutions are excluded from the amnesty law.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: Law No. 2 of 1988 provided amnesty to Panamanians for specific crimes committed between June 1, 1987, and December 24, 1987

narrative: Ley Nº 2 de 5 Jan 1988 Por La Cual Se Concede Amnistía Por Algunos Delitos Políticos, or Law 2 of 1/4/88, was approved by Panama’s Legislative Assembly and went into effect on January 5, 1988. This legislation grants amnesty to Panamanian citizens, who participated, were accused and prosecuted for crimes specified in Chapter 1, title 3, Article 306 of Title 9 Chapter 2, and Article 372 of Title 12, Chapter 1 of the Second Book of the Criminal Code. To be granted an amnesty, these crimes had to be committed between June 1, 1987 and December 24, 1987.

narrative: After taking office in September 1994 President Ernesto Pérez Balladares gave amnesties to 222 friends of former dictator, Noriega. The Vice-President (VP), Tomas Altamirano Duque also granted 130 pardons to other friends of Noreiga. The VP and others in the administration were known as “puppets” under Noreiga’s control so the pardons were essentially created for those who are loyal to Noreiga. This amnesty covers those who have been accused or convicted, but it does not cover members of the opposing political group.

narrative: There were a series of amnesty laws in Panama in 1994. The first one was on July 7, 1994. On this day, President Endara granted pardons to 578 former state officials, who were accused of political crimes under the former dictator, Noreiga. These political crimes were widespread, including corruption to the murder of an American teacher. The pardon gave legal amnesty to many who played small roles under Noreiga, but excluded those who were Noreiga’s closest military associates. These associates remained in prison. On June 26, 1994, the Former Chief of State of the Armed Forces, Colonel Roberto Diaz Herrara, who was convicted and sentenced to five years of imprisonment, was also granted amnesty. This amnesty is supposed to exclude torture.
whoWasAmnestied: state agents; protesters / political prisoners; armed opposition

mechanismDescription: Law No. 26479 provided a general amnesty to military, police, and civilian government personnel for all crimes committed in the course of combating terrorism from May 1980 to June 15, 1995
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi n° 26479 prévoit une amnistie générale pour les militaires, les policiers et le personnel civil du gouvernement pour tous les crimes commis dans le cadre de la lutte contre le terrorisme entre mai 1980 et le 15 juin 1995.
amnestyName: Ley No. 26479 and related Ley No. 26492
narrative: Ley Nº 26479 Conceden amnistía general a personal militar, political y civil para diversos casos of June 14, 1995 was later modified by Ley Nº 26492 Precisan interpretación y alcances de amnistía otogada por la Ley Nº 26479 (28 Jun 1995), published in Normas Legales. The Democratic Constituent Congress passed the law and then President Fujimori promulgated it. It went into effect on June 16, 1995. It was a blanket amnesty that pardoned military and police members regardless of status, “who face a complaint, investigation, criminal charge, trial, or conviction for common or military crimes, whether under the jurisdiction of the civilian or military courts, in relation to all events derived from, or originating in, or as a consequence of, the fight against terrorism, and which may have been committed individually or by two or more persons between May 1980” and the day the amnesty went into effect (Article 1). In other words, the amnesty covers crimes of torture, forced disappearances, and extrajudicial killings along with fraud and arms purchases. Though the amnesty seems broad, it excluded insurgents. Opinion polls estimated that 80% of the Peruvian population did not support the amnesty legislation.

mechanismDescription: In July 2024, Peru's Congress enacted a controversial law introducing a statute of limitations for crimes against humanity and war crimes committed before July 1, 2002.
mechanismDescription_fr: En juillet 2024, le Congrès péruvien a adopté une loi controversée introduisant un délai de prescription pour les crimes contre l'humanité et les crimes de guerre commis avant le 1er juillet 2002.
narrative: The law establishes that crimes against humanity and war crimes committed before July 1, 2002, are subject to the national statute of limitations. This effectively means that such crimes can no longer be prosecuted if the statute of limitations has expired, potentially leading to the dismissal of ongoing cases related to Peru's internal armed conflict between 1980 and 2000. The primary groups involved within the period of violence in Peru included state agents and armed rebel groups The Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso - SL) and Túpac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA - Movimiento Revolucionario Túpac Amaru).
qualifyingProcess: Individuals implicated in crimes against humanity or war crimes committed before July 1, 2002, may benefit from the statute of limitations established by this law, leading to the dismissal of ongoing prosecutions or the nullification of convictions.

mechanismDescription_fr: Proclamation n° 1092 Amnistie accordée aux membres du Rebolusyonaryong Partido Ng Manggagawa Ng Pilipinas/Revolutionary Proletarian Army/Alex Boncayao Brigade (Rpmp-Rpa-Abb) qui ont commis des crimes punissables en vertu du code pénal révisé et des lois pénales spéciales dans le cadre de leurs convictions politiques.
narrative: Proclamation No.1092 was proclaimed by President Duterte on the 5th of February. It was passed unanimously by the Philippine's House of Representatives on May19th, 2021 and enacted on January 24th, 2022. The proclamation provided amnesty to members of the armed rebel groups Rebolusyonaryong Partido Ng Manggagawa Ng Pilipinas/Revolutionary Proletarian Army/Alex Boncayao Brigade (Rpmp-Rpa-Abb). The proclamation was enacted through the National Amnesty Commission, which was created on 05/02/2021 through executive Order No.125. The amnesty came in the tenure of President Duterte's policy of reintegration and reconciliation with rebel groups within the country.
qualifyingProcess: 1) Individual applications and deadlines: From Proclamation No. 1092 Section 6 “Application Period. - Applications for the grant of amnesty shall be filed under oath with the Amnesty Commission within one (1) year from the effectivity of this Proclamation.” 2) Disarmament and demobilization: From Proclamation No. 1092 Section 2 “An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application.” 3) Truth telling From Proclamation No. 1092 Section 2 "An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability' for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application."

mechanismDescription: Proclamation No.1090 granted Amnesty to Members of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) Who Have Committed Crimes Punishable Under the Revised Penal Code and Special Penal Laws in Furtherance of Their Political Beliefs.
mechanismDescription_fr: La proclamation n° 1090 accorde l'amnistie aux membres du Front islamique de libération moro (MILF) qui ont commis des crimes punissables en vertu du code pénal révisé et des lois pénales spéciales dans le cadre de leurs convictions politiques.
narrative: Proclamation No.1090 was proclaimed by President Duteres on 5th February 2021. It was passed unanimously by the Philippine's House of Representatives on February 05, 2021 by the House of Representatives on 19 May 2021 and by the Senate on 24 January 2022, upon which it came into effect. The proclamation provided amnesty to members of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). The amnesty was enacted through the National Amnesty Commission, which was created on 05/02/2021 through executive Order No.125. The amnesty followed after the intra-state conflict ended with the Comprehensive Agreement on the Bangsamoro in 2014. Representatives of the government and the MILF signed the pact, including power-sharing and wealth-sharing agreements, in Manila on March 27, 2014. More than 100,000 individuals were killed during the conflict. More than one million individuals were displaced during the conflict. The amnesty came in the tenure of President Duterte's policy of reintegration and reconciliation with rebel groups within the country.
qualifyingProcess: Individual applications and deadlines From Proclamation No. 1090 Section 6 “Application Period. - Applications for the grant of amnesty shall be filed under oath with the Amnesty Commission within one (1) year from the effectivity of this Proclamation.” Disarmament and demobilization From Proclamation No. 1090 Section 2 “An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application.” Truth telling From Proclamation No. 1090 Section 2 "An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability' for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application."

narrative: The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) was founded in the Philippines in 1972. It started as a splinter group of the Muslim Independence Movement. The group was amnestied through Proclamation 1091 that was passed unanimously by the House of Representatives of the Philippines. Proclamation No. 1091 was officially passed on February 05, 2021. It was enacted later on the 24th of January 2022. The amnesty was enacted by the National Amnesty Commission created in February of 2021 through executive order 125. The amnesty, proposed by President Duterte, reflects upon a policy shift in reintegration and reconciliation with armed resistance groups in the Philippines.
qualifyingProcess: Details to qualify for the amnesty were mentioned within the proclamation. Individual applications and deadlines From Proclamation No. 1091 Section 6 “Application Period. - Applications for the grant of amnesty shall be filed under oath with the Amnesty Commission within one (1) year from the effectivity of this Proclamation.” Disarmament and demobilization From Proclamation No. 1091 Section 2 “An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application.” Truth telling From Proclamation No. 1091 Section 2 "An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability' for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application."

mechanismDescription: Proclamation no. 405, s. 2023 granted amnesty to members of the moro islamic liberation front (milf) who have committed crimes punishable under the revised penal code and special penal laws in furtherance of political beliefs.
mechanismDescription_fr: La proclamation n° 405, article 2023, accorde l'amnistie aux membres du Front moro de libération islamique (milf) qui ont commis des crimes punissables en vertu du code pénal révisé et des lois pénales spéciales au nom de leurs convictions politiques.
narrative: Presidential Adviser Carlito Galvez Jr. on Peace, Reconciliation, and Unity stated in his statement on Friday that the Proclamations will provide greater opportunities to the MILF in participating and engaging with the broader community as their social and political rights get restored. MILF Chairman Al Haj Murad Ebrahim said he highly welcomes the issuance of the Proclamations No. 405 on November 22, which will allow qualified former MILF combatants to get a new lease in life and seize the opportunity for healing and reconciliation through the President’s amnesty grant.
qualifyingProcess: As per Section 2. Who May File for Amnesty. - Any member of the MILF who has committed any act or omission in pursuit of political belief, referred to in Section 1 hereof, including those detained, charged, or convicted for such acts or omissions, may file an application for amnesty; Provided that, the crime for which amnesty may be granted must have been committed prior to the issuance of this Proclamation. A person who has already been granted amnesty under previous amnesty proclamations shall no longer qualify to apply for amnesty under this Proclamation. For avoidance of doubt, persons who applied for amnesty under previous proclamations whose applications were not considered for having been made outside the reglementary period for filing may apply under this Proclamation. An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application. The filing of an application herein shall not ipso fact° result in a grant of amnesty. Applicants who are found qualified, upon due deliberation of the commission, created for this purpose and approved by the President, shall be issued the corresponding Certificate of Amnesty.
whatCrimes: dissent / political crimes; regular crime; armed opposition

narrative: "The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) lauded the issuance of Proclamation No. 406 by President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr., granting amnesty to its members who wish to return to the fold of the law as “it serves as a vehicle to ever-lasting unity, peace and reconciliation.” In a statement, the Office of Deputy Speaker Ustadz Abdulkarim Tan Misuari said that President Marcos’ Proclamation No. 406 is a bold move, showcasing his commitment towards unity, peace and reconciliation. “Extending amnesty to the members of the MNLF by issuing Proclamation No. 406, dated November 22, 2023, President Marcos, Jr. has displayed his genuine desire to heal the wounds of the past and foster brotherhood,” Misuari said. He added that the proclamation amnesty also “serves as a significant step towards national unity, and promotes a peaceful and a more inclusive nation.” President Marcos issued the said proclamation on November 22, granting amnesty to MNLF members who have committed offenses punishable under the Revised Penal Code and special penal laws, among others, in furtherance of their political beliefs. The President cited that granting amnesty to MNLF members will create a climate conducive for peace and reconciliation, pave the way for them to reintegrate into the society, and provide them access to government’s socio-economic services."
qualifyingProcess: "As per Section 2. Who May File for Amnesty. - Any member of the MNLF who has committed any act or omission in pursuit of political belief, referred to in Section 1 hereof, including those detained, charged, or convicted for such acts or omissions, may file an application for amnesty; Provided that, the crime for which amnesty may be granted must have been committed prior to the issuance of this Proclamation. A person who has already been granted amnesty under previous amnesty proclamations shall no longer qualify to apply for amnesty under this Proclamation. For avoidance of doubt, persons who applied for amnesty under previous proclamations whose applications were not considered for having been made outside the reglementary period for filing may apply under this Proclamation. An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offense for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application. The filing of an application herein shall not ipso fact° result in a grant of amnesty. Applicants who are found qualified, upon due deliberation of the commission, created for this purpose and approved by the President, shall be issued the corresponding Certificate of Amnesty.

mechanismDescription: Under Proclamation No. 404, President Marcos granted amnesty to the former members of the CPP-NPA-NDF who have committed crimes punishable under the Revised Penal Code and Special Penal laws in furtherance of their political beliefs, among other offenses.
mechanismDescription_fr: En vertu de la proclamation n° 404, le président Marcos a amnistié les anciens membres du CPP-NPA-NDF qui ont commis des crimes punissables en vertu du code pénal révisé et des lois pénales spéciales en faveur de leurs convictions politiques, entre autres infractions.
narrative: "The proclamation follows the prior Proclamation No.1093. One notable difference is that Proclamation No. 1093 referred to the “Communist Terrorist Group (CTG)” while its new counterpart Proclamation No. 404 refers to the CPP-NPA-NDF. The proclamation has simmilar legal foundations as the previous proclamation. The President also signed Executive Order 47 amending the functions of the National Amnesty Commission (NAC) to cover the processing of applications for amnesty under the new proclamations. Records showed that there are 1,576 remaining members of the CPP-NPA-NDF with 1,406 firearms. Office of the Presidential Adviser on Peace, Reconciliation and Unity (OPAPRU) Secretary Carlito Galvez Jr. said that they are expecting around 1500 members to apply
qualifyingProcess: "As per section 1: Grant of Amnesty. - Amnesty is hereby granted to members of the CPP-NPA-NDF who have committed crimes in pursuit of their political beliefs, whether punishable under the Revised Penal Code or special penal laws, including but not limited to the following: a. Rebellion or insurrection; b. Conspiracy and proposal to commit rebellion or insurrection; c. Disloyalty of public officers or employees; d. Inciting to rebellion or insurrection; e. Sedition; f. Conspiracy to commit sedition; g. Inciting to sedition; h. Illegal assembly; i. Illegal association; j. Direct assault; k. Indirect assault; l. Resistance and disobedience to a person in authority or the agents of such person; m. Tumults and other disturbances of public order; n. Unlawful use of means of publication and unlawful utterances; o. Alarms and scandals; p. Illegal possession of firearms, ammunition or explosives, provided that these crimes or offenses were committed in furtherance of, incident to, or in connection with the crimes of rebellion or insurrection; and q. Those charged, detained or convicted of common crimes but who can establish by substantial evidence that they have actually committed said crimes in pursuit of political beliefs. Section 2. Who May File for Amnesty. - Any member of the CPP-NPA-NDF who has committed any act or omission in pursuit of political belief, referred to in Section 1 hereof, including those detained, charged, or convicted for such acts or omissions, may file an application for amnesty; Provided that, the crime for which amnesty may be granted must have been committed prior to the issuance of this Proclamation. For purposes of this proclamation, a ""former member"" is understood to refer to one who was a former member of the CPP-NPA-NDF or their front organizations, has surrendered to the government, and renounced his rebellious activities. A person who has already been granted amnesty under previous amnesty proclamations shall no longer qualify to apply for amnesty under this Proclamation. For avoidance of doubt, persons who applied for amnesty under previous proclamations whose applications were not considered for having been made outside the reglementary period for filing may apply under this Proclamation. An applicant under this Proclamation must, in writing and under oath, admit his or her guilt of the offence for which he or she is criminally liable and shall turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives he or she may have in his or her possession upon application for amnesty without incurring liability for illegal possession thereof, notwithstanding the grant or denial of the amnesty application. The filing of an application herein shall not ipso fact° result in a grant of amnesty. Applicants who are found qualified, upon due deliberation of the commission, created for this purpose and approved by the President, shall be issued the corresponding Certificate of Amnesty."
whatCrimes: dissent / political crimes; regular crime; armed opposition
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty

A person who has already been granted amnesty under previous amnesty proclamations will no longer qualify to apply. An applicant must admit guilt of the offense for which he is criminally liable and turn over whatever firearms, weapons, and/or explosives in his possession upon application for amnesty. The filing of an application shall not ipso facto (by the fact itself) result in a grant of amnesty, according to the proclamations. “Applicants who are found qualified, upon due deliberation of the commission created for this purpose and approved by the President, shall be issued the corresponding Certificate of Amnesty,”"

mechanismDescription: The government offered an amnesty to Islamic insurgents
mechanismDescription_fr: Le gouvernement a offert une amnistie aux insurgés islamiques.
narrative: The purpose of this amnesty was to "offer a chance for whoever belongs to the misguided group [al Qaeda] and is still at large following involvement in terrorism operations to repent, plead guilty and voluntarily surrender" (NYTIMES). It seems as if the amnesty was targeted mainly toward new recruits of al Qaeda, rather than those who already had engaged in attacks. It was also not expected to cover leaders of al Qaeda responsible for killings. Crown Prince Abdullah said in a televised address, on behalf of King Fahd, that militants who turn themselves in will be treated fairly under God's law and spared the death penalty. But those who didn't will invoke the wrath of a government that derives its power from god. Mohsen al-Awaji, an Islamist lawyer who sought to mediate between the government and militants, said 'God's law" meant those who gave themselves up would not face state prosecution but would be subject to civil charges. Prince Faisal said that "the state will drop its claim on these criminals if they give themselves in, but the private claims of the families of those who were killed or who were assaulted or who were wounded will remain for them to decide" (Mallinder).
qualifyingProcess: - time limit of one month - Must surrender voluntarily to security forces.

mechanismDescription: The Senegal Amnesty Law of 2024 was enacted to address political tensions and conflicts resulting from protests between March 2021 and February 2024, which left over 60 people dead. The law pardoned individuals involved in political protests and related offenses during this period, including those charged with unauthorized demonstrations, public order disturbances, and politically motivated acts.
mechanismDescription_fr: La loi d'amnistie sénégalaise de 2024 a été promulguée pour répondre aux tensions politiques et aux conflits résultant des manifestations qui ont eu lieu entre mars 2021 et février 2024 et qui ont fait plus de 60 morts. La loi a gracié les personnes impliquées dans des manifestations politiques et des infractions connexes au cours de cette période, y compris les personnes accusées de manifestations non autorisées, de troubles à l'ordre public et d'actes à motivation politique.
narrative: The context for the amnesty was Senegal's political instability, marked by opposition protests, violent clashes with security forces, and arrests of high-profile figures like opposition leader Ousmane Sonko. The law aimed to ease political tensions ahead of the rescheduled presidential election in March 2024, promoting reconciliation by facilitating the release of detainees, including Sonko and his ally Bassirou Diomaye Faye.
qualifyingProcess: Participation in Politically Motivated Actions: The law applies to individuals involved in acts classified as criminal or correctional offenses during political protests and related activities between March 2021 and February 2024. This includes participation in unauthorized demonstrations, public disturbances linked to opposition protests, and politically motivated actions aimed at challenging state authority or advocating political reforms. Timeframe: The actions had to have occurred between March 2021 and February 2024, aligning with the period of significant political unrest in Senegal. Context of Actions: Actions had to be directly related to political protests or demonstrations tied to political opposition movements during this period.

Certains analystes considèrent cette mesure comme un moyen de retirer les combattants d'Al-Shabab du champ de bataille, ce qui affaiblirait le groupe d'insurgés.
amnestyName: Executive Decree by President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud
narrative: The announcement by the National Counter Terrorism Center to open doors for defections follows President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud's remarks that al-Shabab leadership was not willing to negotiate with the government. Abdiaziz Hussein Issack, a security analyst with Hamad Bin Khalifa Civilization Center, said the amnesty offer to al-Shabab is a strategic tactic by the Somali government to further weaken the group. Already, he said, there have been reports of discontent among the foot soldiers that they are not getting support from the top leadership as the government forces pile pressure on them.
qualifyingProcess: The amnesty was intended to encourage individual members of Al Shabaab to surrender and hand in their weapons.

qualifyingProcess: - The deadline for the submission of applications was extended from 6 Dec 1996, to 30 Sep 1997. - The Amnesty Committee consists of three judges and two lawyers. It is empowered to recommend amnesty for any applicant who fulfils certain criteria including inter alia that the person makes a full disclosure of the facts. Firstly, the applicant was required to submit a written application on the prescribed amnesty application form and this application had to be made under oath and attested by a commissioner of oaths. Secondly, where necessary the applicant may be called to appear before a public hearing of the Amnesty Committee.

qualifyingProcess: The government repealed the system by which ?ideological prisoners? had to renounce their real or alleged beliefs and instituted a system by which prisoners had to sign a written promise to obey the law, including the National Security Law, and pledge to recognize the Republic of Korea in order to be released from prison. The ?oath of law-abidance? system does not operate by compulsion, but requests an oath from prisoners that they abide by the law. The oath is not a prerequisite for release, as the release under 22 Feb 1999 and 15 Aug 1999 amnesties without giving the oath of 49 persons convicted for violations of the National Security Law shows.

narrative: The amnesty aimed to facilitate peace negotiations and promote national reconciliation by encouraging opposition groups to lay down arms and engage in dialogue. The government of South Sudan and SSOMA begun talks in Italy where they signed the Rome Declaration on Jan. 13 and agreed to continue with peace talks. The SSOMA is a coalition of nine opposition groups made up of ex-government and military officials who refused to be part of the September 2018 peace deal.

amnestyName: Republican Order No.1/2022 for the Grant of Amnesty to the SPLA-IO Kitgwang Faction and Agwelek Forces.
narrative: The amnesty was part of efforts to revitalize the peace process by incorporating armed opposition factions into the national army and political framework, thereby reducing hostilities and fostering national unity.
qualifyingProcess: Belonging to the specified factions and agreeing to the terms of the peace agreement, including cessation of hostilities and integration into national structures. The order reads: In exercise of powers conferred upon me under Article 101 (c) read together with Article 153 (1) of the transitional constitution of South Sudan 2011 (as amended), I Salva Kiir Mayardit, President of Republic of South Sudan and commander-in-chief of SSPDF (South Sudan People's Defence Force), do hereby issue this republican order for the grant of amnesty to the SPLA-IO Kitgwang faction and Agwelek forces under the respective commands of Gen Simon Gatwech Dual and Lt Gen Johnson Olony Tobu with effect from 17 January 2022.

mechanismDescription: The Spanish Parliament passed an amnesty law aimed at addressing the political and social tensions arising from Catalonia's pro-independence activities between 2012 and 2023. This legislation pardons individuals involved in these events, including public servants and law enforcement officers who participated in or supported the independence process. Therefore, the amnesty applies not only to Catalan activists but also to state police officers implicated in related actions.
mechanismDescription_fr: Le Parlement espagnol a adopté une loi d'amnistie visant à répondre aux tensions politiques et sociales résultant des activités indépendantistes de la Catalogne entre 2012 et 2023. Cette loi gracie les personnes impliquées dans ces événements, y compris les fonctionnaires et les agents des forces de l'ordre qui ont participé au processus d'indépendance ou l'ont soutenu. Par conséquent, l'amnistie s'applique non seulement aux activistes catalans, mais aussi aux agents de la police nationale impliqués dans des actions connexes.
amnestyName: Organic Law on the Amnesty for Institutional, Political and Social Normalisation in Catalonia.
narrative: The Spanish Parliament passed the Organic Law on the Amnesty for Institutional, Political and Social Normalisation in Catalonia on May 30, 2024, following a heated parliamentary debate. The Socialist Party, led by Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, spearheaded the initiative, narrowly securing its passage with 177 votes in favor and 172 against. The legislative process included multiple deliberations, with the government justifying the law as a reconciliatory measure to address political tensions from Catalonia's independence efforts. The amnesty targets individuals involved in Catalonia’s pro-independence activities between 2012 and 2023, including politicians, activists, and public servants. It also extends to state police implicated in actions tied to enforcing laws during this period, reflecting its broader aim of reconciliation. Responses to the law were polarized. Supporters viewed it as a step toward political normalization and coexistence, while critics condemned it as undermining the rule of law, with some even questioning its constitutionality
qualifyingProcess: To qualify for amnesty under the Organic Law on the Amnesty for Institutional, Political and Social Normalisation in Catalonia, individuals needed to have engaged in specific actions tied to the pro-independence process in Catalonia. These actions are outlined in legislation and include: 1. Participation in the Pro-Independence Process - Organizing or supporting the unconstitutional 2014 consultation and the 2017 referendum. - Promoting or facilitating Catalonia's secession or independence. - Engaging in acts of disobedience, public disorder, or resistance related to these events. 2. Supportive Roles: - Providing assistance, security, or advice to pro-independence leaders or initiatives. - Demonstrating public support for pro-independence movements, including symbolic acts like protests or assemblies. 3. Scope of Actions: - The actions must have occurred between **January 1, 2012, and November 13, 2023**. - Preparatory acts or related conduct were included, provided they were connected to the independence process. The law explicitly excluded individuals involved in severe crimes, such as terrorism or acts of violence exceeding a threshold of severity, ensuring only politically motivated actions qualified. Judicial and administrative bodies would evaluate each case for compliance with these criteria.
hrCrimes: human rights crimes were excluded from amnesty

narrative: The Sri Lankan government, under President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, granted presidential pardons to 16 Tamil prisoners who had been convicted under the Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). The PTA has been widely criticized for its harsh provisions that allow prolonged detention without charge, leading to allegations of arbitrary detention and torture, particularly targeting the Tamil minority. The amnesty was seen as a response to growing international pressure, particularly from the United Nations (UN) and human rights organizations, which had urged Sri Lanka to either charge or release those detained under the PTA.
qualifyingProcess: - Being convicted under the PTA for alleged terrorist activities. - Some of those pardoned were due to be released soon, which suggests that the amnesty expedited their scheduled release

mechanismDescription: In October 2020, the Juba Agreement for Peace in Sudan was signed by Sudan’s transitional government and by many of the country’s main warring factions. The agreement is a complex attempt at reconciliation between the warring groups towards system of federalism.
mechanismDescription_fr: En octobre 2020, l'Accord de Juba pour la paix au Soudan a été signé par le gouvernement de transition du Soudan et par plusieurs des principales factions belligérantes du pays. L'accord est une tentative complexe de réconciliation entre les groupes belligérants vers un système de fédéralisme.
narrative: The chair of Sudan’s Sovereign Council, Lt. Gen. Burhan, announced a general amnesty for those who previously carried weapons or participated in military operations in Sudan. This included a multitude of warring factions in South Sudan. Groups part of amnesty were included in different region-centric agreements. These include: Justice and Equality Movement, the Sudan Liberation Movement (Minni Minawi), the Sudan Liberation Movement Transitional Council, the Sudanese Alliance Movement, the Sudan Liberation Forces Alliance, and the Sudan Liberation Movement. Sudan Liberation Movement – North– SRF (الحركة الشعبية لتحرير السودان – شامل\ الجبهة الثورية) Connected to the South Sudanese Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM) and remained active in Sudan after South Sudan seceded in 2011. In 2017, the movement split into two main factions: the Malik Agar faction which signed the Juba Agreement and the Abdelaziz al-Hilu faction which has still not signed into the Agreement. Both factions are located in the South Kordofan and Blue Nile area. Masar al-Sharq (Eastern Path) Headed by Osama Saeed, the leader of the Beja Congress, which is a political group comprising serval ethnic groups. The group has splintered, which contributed to a lack of consensus within Masar al Sharq on the Juba Agreement. Osama Saeed signed the Eastern Sudan Track on behalf of two Beja Congress splinter groups (United People’s Front for Liberation and Justice and the Beja Congress in opposition). Masar al-Shamal (Northern Path) Consists of the Kush Liberation Movement and the North Entity include (حركة تحرير كوش وكيان الشامل) development, and displaced persons in north Sudan, Merowe and Wadi Halfa who were displaced because of dam construction. Masar al-Wasat (Central Path) Coalition of political parties and Sufi groups. Headed by the Revolutionary Democratic Front Party. Masar al-Wasat is concentrated in al-Jazira state, the White Nile, Sennar and the state of Khartoum. Al-Jabaha al-Thalitha-Tamazaj (Third Front
qualifyingProcess: The amnesty was brought into immediate effect after being proclaimed by the Sovereign council. It is stated as per "3(1) – Pardons shall be granted to all those who bore arms or took part in any military or martial operations or participated in any words or actions linked to combat operations

mechanismDescription: This amnesty was decreed during the long-running Syrian Civil War but was not linked to a specific peace process. Many such decrees were instituted directly by the executive during this conflict. The purpose of the decree appears to have been to encourage individuals, such as political dissidents, to surrender to the government.
mechanismDescription_fr: Cette amnistie a été décrétée pendant la longue guerre civile syrienne, mais n'était pas liée à un processus de paix spécifique. De nombreux décrets de ce type ont été institués directement par l'exécutif au cours de ce conflit. L'objectif de ce décret semble avoir été d'encourager les individus, tels que les dissidents politiques, à se rendre au gouvernement.
narrative: The SNHR (2022) observes that “‘taking up arms’ charges were filed against protestors with no proof. This was the Syrian regime’s preferred go-to charge, which was used to persecute political dissidents”, and also observes that some people who surrendered following this amnesty were arrested and forcibly disappeared. The Day After describes this specific amnesty in similar terms. “General amnesty is a tool used by the Syrian regime to pardon criminals, especially from groups in its circle; most provisions of amnesty laws cover smuggling, drugs and crimes involving currency, or they are issued for specific political reasons, while excluding a number of crimes the regime accuses its opponents of” (The Day After 2021)
qualifyingProcess: There is a lack of any clear mechanism for the methods used in selecting and releasing detainees included in the amnesty, as well as a failure to include detainees held, often for years, in security branches and unofficial detention centers, without being charged or subjected to any trial. However, the on-paper mechanisms can be viewed as follows: individual applications and deadlines From Law "Article (20): Persons in hiding and fugitives from justice in felonies covered by the provisions of this Legislative Decree shall not benefit from such amnesty unless they surrender themselves within six months from the date of its issuance to the competent authorities. Article (21): The Minister of Justice, in coordination with the Minister of Defense, shall form the necessary medical committees to examine the beneficiaries of the provisions of Article 3 of this Legislative Decree upon a request submitted by the beneficiary within a maximum period of one month from the date of its issuance. The reports of the medical committees shall be issued by a decision of the Minister of Justice or the Minister of Defense, each in his respective capacity." Contribute to reparations From Law "Article (18): The provisions of this Legislative Decree shall not cover: Fines for violations of customs, cutting, exchange, tobacco, tobacco, building control, electricity and stamp control. All fines stipulated in the laws that bear the character of civil compensation. Article (19): Subject to the provisions of Article 16 of this Legislative Decree, the following conditions shall be required to benefit from its provisions: Payment by the convicted person by a final judgment of the amounts, compensations and obligations awarded in favor of the plaintiff in accordance with the applicable procedures, or submitting the termination of a personal right. With regard to felonies and misdemeanors provided for in Articles 628 to 659 of the Penal Code and its amendments, if the public action has not been initiated or is in the process of trial, the pardon shall not be benefited unless there is a waiver of a personal right, and the injured party may pay the prosecution's advance within thirty days of the entry into force of this legislative decree, and if this period has elapsed and the prosecution has not been submitted, the provisions of this legislative decree shall apply, and in the event of a final judgment, the convicted person shall benefit from the provisions of this legislative decree. By paying the adjudicated obligations, where paying them takes the place of forfeiting the personal right."
whatCrimes: corruption or other economic crimes; dissent / political crimes; regular crime; armed opposition
hrCrimes: human rights crimes are not relevant to this amnesty

mechanismDescription: Syria’s president issued a decree granting amnesty and reducing sentences for several categories of crime. No reason was given for the amnesty but it came on the anniversary of the 1970 coup that brought the father and predecessor of President Bashar Assad to power.
mechanismDescription_fr: Le président syrien a publié un décret accordant l'amnistie et la réduction des peines pour plusieurs catégories de crimes. Aucune raison n'a été donnée pour cette amnistie, mais elle est intervenue à l'occasion de l'anniversaire du coup d'État de 1970 qui a porté au pouvoir le père et prédécesseur du président Bachar Assad.
narrative: Assad has issued similar amnesties since the country’s deadly conflict that has killed half a million people began in March 2011. The decree grants a complete pardon for misdemeanor convictions and people serving prison sentences who have reached the age of 70, or those who have incurable diseases. This amnesty was decreed during the long-running Syrian Civil War but was not linked to a specific peace process. Many such decrees were instituted directly by the executive during this conflict. The SNHR (2023) makes several critical points related to this and similar amnesties having many exceptions and poor implementation. In particular, it argues that the main goal of the amnesty is to provide an amnesty to petty criminals while keeping political prisoners in jail.
qualifyingProcess: Individual applications and deadlines From Law “Article 8 – A - For the full penalty for the following crimes stipulated in the Military Penal Code issued by Legislative Decree No. (61) of 1950 and its amendments: 1- The crime of internal escape stipulated in Article 100. 2- The crime of external escape stipulated in Article 101. 3- The crime of escape stipulated in Paragraph 4 of Article 103. B - The provisions of Paragraph /A/ of this Article do not include those who are in hiding and fleeing from justice unless they surrender themselves within three months for internal flight and six months for external flight. Article 12 – A - The life imprisonment sentence will be replaced with the death penalty. B- The temporary imprisonment sentence for 20 years shall be replaced from the life imprisonment sentence. C- The temporary detention penalty for 20 years is replaced by the life imprisonment penalty. D - The mitigation provisions stipulated in this Article shall not be applied in felonies that result in personal harm unless the injured party has waived his personal right, and payment of the amount of compensation awarded shall not be considered a waiver, and in cases where the injured party has not filed a personal claim, he has the right to file it. Within sixty days from the date of entry into force of this legislative decree, and if this period expires and the claim is not submitted, the mitigation provisions stipulated in this article shall apply. Article 16 – Those who are in hiding and fleeing from justice in crimes partially covered by the provisions of this legislative decree will not benefit from this amnesty unless they surrender themselves within six months from the date of its issuance to the competent authorities. Article 17 – A - The Minister of Justice, in coordination with the Minister of Defense, shall form the necessary medical committees to examine the beneficiaries of the provisions of Article 3 of this Legislative Decree, based on a request submitted by the beneficiary within a maximum period of one month from the date of its issuance. B- Medical committee reports shall be issued by decision of the Minister of Justice or the Minister of Defense, each within his jurisdiction.” Contribute to reparations From Law “Article 12 – A - The life imprisonment sentence will be replaced with the death penalty. B- The temporary imprisonment sentence for 20 years shall be replaced from the life imprisonment sentence. C- The temporary detention penalty for 20 years is replaced by the life imprisonment penalty. D - The mitigation provisions stipulated in this Article shall not be applied in felonies that result in personal harm unless the injured party has waived his personal right, and payment of the amount of compensation awarded shall not be considered a waiver, and in cases where the injured party has not filed a personal claim, he has the right to file it. Within sixty days from the date of entry into force of this legislative decree, and if this period expires and the claim is not submitted, the mitigation provisions stipulated in this article shall apply. Article 15 – Taking into account the provisions of Article 12 of this Legislative Decree, it is required to benefit from its provisions. A- Payment by the convicted person of the sums, compensation and obligations awarded in favor of the plaintiff in accordance with applicable procedures, or submitting a waiver of a personal right. B - With regard to felonies and misdemeanors stipulated in Articles 628 to 659 of the Penal Code promulgated by Legislative Decree No. 148 of 1949 and its amendments, if the public lawsuit has not been initiated or is in the process of being tried, the pardon will not be benefited unless there is a waiver of the right. Personally, the aggrieved party may pay the claim advance within thirty days from the entry into force of this legislative decree. If this period elapses and the claim is not submitted, the provisions of this legislative decree shall apply. In the event of a final judgment being issued, the convicted person shall benefit from the provisions of this legislative decree by paying the obligations imposed upon him as he settles them. The position of extinguishing personal rights."

narrative: Royal Act granting an amnesty 'for offenders in the rallies on 17-21 May’ was an executive decree. It was supported by the Thai King and went into effect on May 24, 1992. The Thai Parliament opposed the decree because it was a public anti-government protest but the public prosecutors worked on it until he became a decree. This amnesty pardons all offenders, who participated in the public demonstration between Mary 17, 1992 and Mary 21, 1992, and the military officers, who used excessive force against the protestors. The legislation led to the immediate release of those detained. When the amnesty was created, it was interpreted to only apply to criminal proceedings, but in 1999, this interpretation expanded to cover civil suits as well as determined by the Supreme Court.

mechanismDescription: The UK parliament voted Tuesday, September 12, to adopt a controversial law granting immunity to combatants involved in the decades of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland known as the Troubles, despite criticism from Ireland and the Council of Europe.
mechanismDescription_fr: Le Parlement britannique a voté mardi 12 septembre en faveur de l'adoption d'une loi controversée accordant l'immunité aux combattants impliqués dans les décennies de violence sectaire en Irlande du Nord, connues sous le nom de « Troubles », malgré les critiques de l'Irlande et du Conseil de l'Europe.
amnestyName: Northern Ireland Troubles (Legacy and Reconciliation Act) 2023
narrative: The law, proposed by the Conservative government in May 2022, called for the creation of a truth and recovery commission offering amnesty to British security personnel and paramilitaries if they cooperate with its inquiries. The legislative act aims to address the legacy of the Northern Ireland Troubles and promote reconciliation by establishing an Independent Commission for Reconciliation and Information Recovery, limiting criminal investigations, legal proceedings, inquests and police complaints, extending the prisoner release scheme in the Northern Ireland (Sentences) Act 1998, and providing for experiences to be recorded and preserved and for events to be studied and memorialised, and to provide for the validity of interim custody orders. Europe's leading rights watchdog, the Council of Europe, has expressed "serious concerns" about the amnesty and its compatibility with the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), of which the UK is a signatory.
qualifyingProcess: Individual applications and deadlines 19 Immunity from prosecution (1) The ICRIR must grant a person (P) immunity from prosecution if conditions A to C are met. (2) Condition A: P has requested the ICRIR to grant P immunity from prosecution. (3) Condition B: the immunity requests panel is satisfied that the ICRIR is in possession of an account (“P’s account”) that— (a) has been given by P, (b) describes conduct by P which is, or includes, conduct forming part of the Troubles (“P’s disclosed conduct”), and (c) is true to the best of P’s knowledge and belief. (4) P’s account may consist of, or include, information which has previously been given by P (whether directly to the ICRIR or otherwise) if, or to the extent that, the immunity requests panel is satisfied that the information is true to the best of P’s knowledge and belief. Truth telling 19 Immunity from prosecution (1) The ICRIR must grant a person (P) immunity from prosecution if conditions A to C are met. (2) Condition A: P has requested the ICRIR to grant P immunity from prosecution. (3) Condition B: the immunity requests panel is satisfied that the ICRIR is in possession of an account (“P’s account”) that— (a) has been given by P, (b) describes conduct by P which is, or includes, conduct forming part of the Troubles (“P’s disclosed conduct”), and (c) is true to the best of P’s knowledge and belief. (4) P’s account may consist of, or include, information which has previously been given by P (whether directly to the ICRIR or otherwise) if, or to the extent that, the immunity requests panel is satisfied that the information is true to the best of P’s knowledge and belief. Penalties for recidivism Grants of immunity: revocation and false statements 26 Subsequent convictions: revocation of immunity (1) If— (a) a person is convicted of an offence under section 27, (b) that offence was committed in the course of requesting the ICRIR to grant the person immunity from prosecution under section 19, and (c) the person was granted the immunity from prosecution, the court which sentences the person for the offence must revoke that grant of immunity from prosecution. (2) If— (a) a person is convicted of a terrorist offence or an offence with a terrorist connection, and (b) the person had been granted immunity from prosecution under section 19 before the offence was committed, the court which sentences the person for that offence must revoke every grant of immunity from prosecution under section 19 given to the person before the offence was committed. (3) For the purposes of subsection (2) a person is convicted of “a terrorist offence or an offence with a terrorist connection” if— (a) the person is convicted of an offence by a court in Northern Ireland and either— (i) the offence is listed in Schedule 1A to the Counter-Terrorism Act 2008, or (ii) the court determines under section 30(2) of that Act that the offence has a terrorist connection; (b) the person is convicted of an offence by a court in England and Wales and either— (i) the offence is listed in Schedule A1 to the Sentencing Code, or (ii) the court determines under section 69 of the Sentencing Code that the offence has a terrorist connection; (c) the person is convicted of an offence by a court in Scotland and either— (i) the offence is listed in Schedule 1A to the Counter-Terrorism Act 2008, or (ii) section 31 of that Act applies to the offence (offences with a terrorist connection in Scotland). (4) Where— (a) an offence is found to have been committed over a period of two or more days, or at some time during a period of two or more days, and (b) a grant of immunity from prosecution is given at any time during that period, that grant of immunity from prosecution is to be regarded for the purposes of subsection (2) as having been given before the offence was committed. (5) A revocation of immunity under this section— (a) has immediate effect; (b) does not prevent a person making a further request for immunity under section 19 (but see Part 2 of Schedule 5 for provision about requests that overlap with revoked immunities). PART 2 NEW REQUEST FOR IMMUNITY AFTER REVOCATION OF PREVIOUS GRANT 6 (1) This paragraph applies where— (a) under section 26, a court revokes immunity from prosecution granted to a person (P) (the “revoked immunity”), (b) P requests the ICRIR to grant P immunity from prosecution (the “new request”), (c) the new request— (i) is made before the revocation and is not concluded at the time of the revocation, or (ii) is made after the revocation, and (d) conditions A to C in section 19 are met in relation to the new request. (2) When dealing with the new request, the duty of the immunity requests panel to decide (under section 19(7)) what immunity should be granted to P has effect subject to sub-paragraphs (3) and (4). (3) The panel must not decide that P should be granted immunity from prosecution for any identified possible offence which was also within the scope of the revoked immunity. (4) When the panel is determining under section 19(9) or (11)(b) a description of offences for which P should be granted immunity from prosecution, the panel must frame the description so that it does not consist of, or include, one or more offences which were also within the scope of the revoked immunity. (5) If the panel decides in accordance with sub-paragraphs (3) and (4) that there are no offences for which P should be granted immunity— (a) the panel must decide that P should not be granted immunity from prosecution, and (b) the ICRIR must not grant P immunity from prosecution (and accordingly section 19(1) does not apply). (6) For the purposes of this paragraph the new request is “concluded” when the ICRIR gives P written notice of the outcome of the request in accordance with section 19(13)(a).

qualifyingProcess: - Executes an agreement acknowledging his allegiance to the US and pledging to fulfil a period of alternate service under the auspices of the Director of Selective Service, and satisfactorily completes such service. Amnesty was based on a programme of earned re-entry through two years of alternate public service. Each member of the armed forces who elects to seek relief through this programme will receive an undesirable discharge. Thereafter, upon satisfactory completion of a period of alternate service prescribed by the Military Department or Department of Transportation, such individual will be entitled to receive, in lieu of his undesirable discharge, a clemency discharge in recognition of his fulfilment of the requirements of the programme. Such clemency discharge shall not bestow entitlement to benefits administered by the Veterans Administration. - Must present themselves to a US Attorney. - Deadline is 31 Mar 1975.
